awd_titl_txt: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track A: A GIS-Based Digital Platform for Promoting Sustainable, Equitable, and Resilient Access to Healthy Foods in Response to Natural Disasters
awd_abstract_narration:
Food security has been increasingly threatened by poor crop production, high food prices, and supply chain failures. There is an urgent need to improve food security in the aftermath of natural disasters, such as flooding, hurricane, and drought. The common food bank approach for hunger relief and disaster response is far from being sustainable and equitable due to its limited nutritious options, reactive operations, and logistical barriers. This CIVIC project aims to create and validate a Geographic Information System (GIS)-based digital platform that not only promotes sustainable and equitable access to healthy foods but also is resilient to natural disasters and supply chain disruptions in the face of a changing climate. Specifically, the platform will help the communities by providing a robust solution to healthy food access. The project will make special consideration of socially vulnerable populations by increasing their food access during crises. Priority and reimbursement are given to economically disadvantaged households; volunteer riders are assigned to help with food delivery for people with limited mobility. Moreover, the platform has the potential to be transferred to and scaled up in other cities or regions since the marginal cost is low. 

The goal of this project is to improve food security during natural disasters by developing a GIS-based, decentralized digital platform with special consideration for socially vulnerable populations. It focuses on conducting a pilot study in the Tampa Bay Area and adopting the sharing economy business model to connect consumers directly with local food growers. The platform builds a map interface to collect and share essential information with the community, integrates GIS to identify the most vulnerable neighborhoods, and matches them with food supplies. It implements a dedicated emergency mode to mitigate food insecurity, inaccessibility, and inequity. The platform, once finished, can crowdsource real-time data via a map interface; spatially match the food demand and supply; optimize the location and route choices for the food delivery; enable hassle-free food purchase for everyone and reimbursement for people in need; switch to an emergency mode to meet the surged demand.

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program—Track A. Living in a changing climate: pre-disaster action around adaptation, resilience, and mitigation—and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
University of South Florida, lemonGRAFT LLC, and local government agencies and organizations in emergency management and food industry worked together to address food security during natural disasters by proposing to develop a GIS-based decentralized digital food platform in the stage 2 of this award (not funded). The proposed platform uses web mapping and geospatial algorithms to identify surged food demand at the neighborhood level and match it with local food growers and suppliers through the sharing-economy business model. This project will help the community of the Tampa Bay Area by providing a robust solution to healthy food access for pre-disaster preparation and mitigation alternative, with a special consideration of socially vulnerable populations.

 

Intellectual Merit

1) This project provides an alternative to traditional approaches such as food bank by developing a decentralized food platform based on sharing economy during disasters. We re-introduce the roles of the food system back into the community and re-define the scale of the agricultural system and making it more accessible. Food resources are crowdsourced from the community and redistributed back to the crowd based on needs. 2) We solve various technological challenges by integrating map and GIS, spatial multi-criteria analysis (SMCA), risk-identification algorithm into one digital platform to seamlessly connect all roles in a food system during crisis. The final product can: switch on the disaster mode for emergency scenarios and switch it off for normal days; crowdsource real-time data via a map interface; fuse various static and dynamic data; identify at-risk neighborhoods and individuals; prioritize the increased food demand from the vulnerable through a series of actions, such as adding incentive to attract more targeted food supplies. 3) We build a diverse, community-led partnership that includes a local start-up company, emergency management agency, agricultural sector, healthcare organizations, educational institutions, concerned citizens; each of them is committed to generate a novel way to gather and deliver healthy foods in response to the needs of vulnerable populations, particularly, socially disadvantaged, during natural disasters.

 

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts to society include: 1) The project benefits the community in the Tampa Bay Area by providing a robust and resilient solution to food access during natural disasters. Built on a decentralized peer-to-peer network, the platform is immune to logistics malfunctions, transportation congestion, and labor shortages. Through our platform and network, community members can help themselves in different roles, including buyers, food providers, volunteer riders, and relief fund providers. 2) The food platform provides socially vulnerable populations with special consideration to increase food access during crisis: priority is given for the economically disadvantaged households; volunteer riders are assigned to help with food delivery for people with limited mobility. Equity is also promoted for food providers, given the low barrier to enter the market without the hassle with food brokers. 3) The platform promotes a sustainable model that works for both disaster and non-disaster time. It has the potential to be transferred and scaled up in other regions given that the digital infrastructure has little marginal cost for expansion. Plus, the study area has many sharable characteristics that can be found in other geographic areas to include there being a large agricultural sector with compounding threats due to climate change.
